intro: Biscutella laevigata var. dasycarpa, commonly known as the hairy-fruited biscuitroot, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The species is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in early spring. Its fruit is a distinctive, spherical capsule that is covered in short, stiff hairs. This plant is often found in rocky soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments.
